segment.source: To control what drive encryption tasks the user can perform from the Windows Control Panel or to modify other configuration options, you can use Group Policy administrative templates or local computer policy settings.
segment.target: To control what drive encryption tasks the user can perform from the Windows Control Panel or to modify other configuration options, you can use Group Policy administrative templates or local computer policy settings.

segment.source: How you configure these policy settings depends on how you implement BitLocker and what level of user interaction will be allowed.
segment.target: How you configure these policy settings depends on how you implement BitLocker and what level of user interaction will be allowed.

segment.source: Note: A separate set of Group Policy settings supports the use of the Trusted Platform Module (TPM).
segment.target: Note: A separate set of Group Policy settings supports the use of the Trusted Platform Module (TPM).

segment.source: For details about those settings, see Trusted Platform Module Group Policy settings.
segment.target: For details about those settings, see Trusted Platform Module Group Policy settings.

segment.source: BitLocker Group Policy settings can be accessed using the Local Group Policy Editor and the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) under Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsBitLocker Drive Encryption.
segment.target: BitLocker Group Policy settings can be accessed using the Local Group Policy Editor and the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) under Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsBitLocker Drive Encryption.

segment.source: Most of the BitLocker Group Policy settings are applied when BitLocker is initially turned on for a drive.
segment.target: Most of the BitLocker Group Policy settings are applied when BitLocker is initially turned on for a drive.

segment.source: If a computer is not compliant with existing Group Policy settings, BitLocker may not be turned on or modified until the computer is in a compliant state.
segment.target: If a computer is not compliant with existing Group Policy settings, BitLocker may not be turned on or modified until the computer is in a compliant state.

segment.source: When a drive is out of compliance with Group Policy settings (for example, if a Group Policy setting was changed after the initial BitLocker deployment in your organization, and then the setting was applied to previously encrypted drives), no change can be made to the BitLocker configuration of that drive except a change that will bring it into compliance.
segment.target: When a drive is out of compliance with Group Policy settings (for example, if a Group Policy setting was changed after the initial BitLocker deployment in your organization, and then the setting was applied to previously encrypted drives), no change can be made to the BitLocker configuration of that drive except a change that will bring it into compliance.

segment.source: If multiple changes are necessary to bring the drive into compliance, you must suspend BitLocker protection, make the necessary changes, and then resume protection.
segment.target: If multiple changes are necessary to bring the drive into compliance, you must suspend BitLocker protection, make the necessary changes, and then resume protection.

segment.source: This situation could occur, for example, if a removable drive was initially configured to be unlocked with a password and then Group Policy settings are changed to disallow passwords and require smart cards.
segment.target: This situation could occur, for example, if a removable drive was initially configured to be unlocked with a password and then Group Policy settings are changed to disallow passwords and require smart cards.

segment.source: In this situation, you need to suspend BitLocker protection by using the Manage-bde command-line tool, delete the password unlock method, and add the smart card method.
segment.target: In this situation, you need to suspend BitLocker protection by using the Manage-bde command-line tool, delete the password unlock method, and add the smart card method.

segment.source: After this is complete, BitLocker is compliant with the Group Policy setting and BitLocker protection on the drive can be resumed.
segment.target: After this is complete, BitLocker is compliant with the Group Policy setting and BitLocker protection on the drive can be resumed.

segment.source: About PCR 7
segment.target: About PCR 7

segment.source: PCR 7 measures the state of Secure Boot.
segment.target: PCR 7 measures the state of Secure Boot.

segment.source: With PCR 7, BitLocker can leverage Secure Boot for integrity validation.
segment.target: With PCR 7, BitLocker can leverage Secure Boot for integrity validation.

segment.source: Secure Boot ensures that the computer's preboot environment loads only firmware that is digitally signed by authorized software publishers.
segment.target: Secure Boot ensures that the computer's preboot environment loads only firmware that is digitally signed by authorized software publishers.

segment.source: PCR 7 measurements indicate whether Secure Boot is on and which keys are trusted on the platform.
segment.target: PCR 7 measurements indicate whether Secure Boot is on and which keys are trusted on the platform.

segment.source: If Secure Boot is on and the firmware measures PCR 7 correctly per the UEFI specification, BitLocker can bind to this information rather than to PCRs 0, 2, and 4 which have the measurements of the exact firmware and Bootmgr images loaded.
segment.target: If Secure Boot is on and the firmware measures PCR 7 correctly per the UEFI specification, BitLocker can bind to this information rather than to PCRs 0, 2, and 4 which have the measurements of the exact firmware and Bootmgr images loaded.

segment.source: This reduces the likelihood of BitLocker starting in recovery mode as a result of firmware and image updates, and it provides you with greater flexibility to manage the preboot configuration.
segment.target: This reduces the likelihood of BitLocker starting in recovery mode as a result of firmware and image updates, and it provides you with greater flexibility to manage the preboot configuration.

segment.source: PCR 7 measurements must follow the guidance that is described in Appendix A Trusted Execution Environment EFI Protocol.
segment.target: PCR 7 measurements must follow the guidance that is described in Appendix A Trusted Execution Environment EFI Protocol.

segment.source: PCR 7 measurements are a mandatory logo requirement for systems that support InstantGo (also known as Always On, Always Connected PCs), such as the Microsoft Surface RT.
segment.target: PCR 7 measurements are a mandatory logo requirement for systems that support InstantGo (also known as Always On, Always Connected PCs), such as the Microsoft Surface RT.

segment.source: On such systems, if the TPM with PCR 7 measurement and Secure Boot are correctly configured, BitLocker binds to PCR 7 and PCR 11 by default.
segment.target: On such systems, if the TPM with PCR 7 measurement and Secure Boot are correctly configured, BitLocker binds to PCR 7 and PCR 11 by default.
